messages.text: ^ The idea Zhou is discussing there is called “abstraction” or “designing to an interface”.  It’s one of the most important concepts in programming (in general, it appears in all approaches to programming, procedural, oop, functional).

yes, almost everything in python is an object. The beauty of object oriented programming is that you can use an object at an abstract level,  by only knowing its input/output but no need to know all details of how it gets implemented.

Thanks, Zhou.  I’m going to look at it for another hour or so and call it a night.  There is something about how the likelihood function is used that I can’t understand. It might be a conceptual problem that’s more about object orientation than your code itself.  I can’t get my head to accept the idea that a function is an object that you can create, pass around, and use later.

Hey all, I meant to mention this in class:
I think Jack has a fair point there.

Re CDF vs PDF/PMF: Matt and I sometimes have slightly different views :slightly_smiling_face: The big problem with CDFs is the graphs are harder to visualize; they all tend to look pretty similar, at least, more similar than the PDF/PMFs do. So while I agree the CDF is more “fundamental”, I find that if I want to understand a distribution the PDF/PMF is usually more helpful.

Just want to share one of my favorite probability cheat sheet <http://www.wzchen.com/probability-cheatsheet>

With triple backticks:

```
npts =1000
xmin, xmax = -5,5.
dist = scs.norm(0,1)
x = np.linspace(xmin,xmax,npts)
pdf =dist.pdf(x)


print "Calculated variance: {}".format(np.sum((x-dist.mean())**2*pdf)*((xmax-xmin)/npts))
print "Actual variance: {}".format(dist.var())
```
Protip: Use backticks when pasting code in slack.

xmin, xmax = -5,5.

messages.text: <@U2DA7L1D2> Thanks a lot!
lol
So overall, we take something like `<username>Matt</username>`, capture the `Matt` within the tags, then replace the entire thing with just what we captured, which is `Matt`.
`\1` refers to the thing we captured in the regular expression, i.e. whatever was matched inside the parenthesis.
Then in the thing to replace with

```
[ \t]*   (any number of spaces or tabs in a row)
<username>   (the literal string <username>)
\(   (Begin capturing this text for use later)
.*    (Any number of any charecters whatsoever)
\)   (End capturing the text)
<\/username)>  (The literal string </usermame>, we have to escape the slash)
```
And the thing to replace is a regular expression, so it matches text
sed commands look like this `s/thing to replace/thing to replace with/`

cat filename | sed 's/[ \t]*<username>\(.*\)<\/username>/\1/' | sort | uniq -c | sort -rn | head

messages.text: I’m still baffled by ‘git merge,’ but I have all weekend to work it out.  If anyone else is working on this, among the more useful websites for ‘git’ are <https://speakerdeck.com/mgapatrick/git-how-to-unfuck> and <http://rogerdudler.github.io/git-guide/>

Friends, I have spent the last 6 hours or so learning more about git.  Among other things, I’ve learned that LOTS of people use it because they ‘have to’ and work around it when they can. <https://xkcd.com/1597/>

attachments.text: [Title text] "If that doesn't fix it, git.txt contains the phone number of a friend of mine who understands git. Just wait through a few minutes of 'It's really pretty simple, just think of branches as...' and eventually you'll learn the commands that will fix everything."
attachments.title: Git

If you want to run jupyter notebook from the same directory every time without having to cd into that directory everytime you `jupyter notebook`, here's a little template for creating an alias you can run in terminal:
`alias opennb='cd ~/Documents && jupyter notebook'`
`\mathregular` classy.

So if you want LaTeX to render like regular text, you can do this:
```
ax.set_xlabel(r'$\mathregular{\beta_0}$')
ax.set_ylabel(r'$\mathregular{\beta_1}$')
```

New matplotlib code:

```
# x will be the left hand edge of the bars.
x = np.arange(len(record_counts['genre']))

fig, ax = plt.subplots()

bars = ax.bar(x, record_counts['count'])
# Make the ticks at the center of the bar using:
#   center = left_edge + 0.5*width
ax.set_xticks(x)
ax.set_xticklabels(record_counts['genre'])
```
<http://colororacle.org/>

```
fig, axs = plt.subplots(2, 3)

for i, row in enumerate(axs):
    for j, ax in enumerate(row):
        ax.set_title("Plot: {}".format((i, j)))
        
fig.tight_layout()
```

Matplotlib axes API: <https://matplotlib.org/api/axes_api.html>

Hey y’all, here’s some information on the upcoming assessment next monday:

Assessment 2 (the first scored assessment) will cover basics of python programming, basic pandas manipulation, and SQL.  You will have 60 mins to complete this assessment. The assessment is open book and internet. 

```
The structure of all the problems are "fill in the body of this function", as you have seen in the first assessment.

  - There are four problems on core python, manipulating lists, dictionaries, and strings.
  - There are three questions on core pandas manipulations.  Arithmetic, indexing, and grouping.
  - There are three questions on SQL queries.  Selection, subsetting, and grouping.

Please be sure to *read the entire assessment before beginning*.  Start your work where you are most confident, and work towards problems you anticipate are more difficult for you.  Keep an ipython REPL open to try snippets of code.  Run the included tests.
```

We will start at 8:30 sharp, so please prioritize being here on time. 

If you would like practice I would suggest:

  - Redoing problems on the initial assessment and checking your work over with an instructor if unsure about it.  Prioritize the topics covered in the upcoming assessment.
  - I’ve written some extra practice problems in this repo: <https://github.com/zipfian/100-ds-problems/blob/master/100-problems.md> . The core python and pandas problems should be good practice.
Sup y'all. Don't forget about picture day, that's the worst :neutral_face:
SQL solutions are posted. Let me know if you have questions!

If anyone's jupyter notebook isn't auto launching a new tab/window in their browser, here's what worked for me: <https://github.com/jupyter/notebook/issues/2438>

Just add `c.NotebookApp.browser = u'Chrome'` to your config file (probably) located here `~/.jupyter/jupyter_notebook_config.py`

messages.text: <@U3P94SBGF|pmende> pinned a message to this channel.
Here’s git completion:  <https://raw.githubusercontent.com/git/git/master/contrib/completion/git-completion.bash>

```
# Setup git environment.
source ~/.git-completion.sh
source ~/.git-prompt.sh

# Colors
green="\[\033[0;32m\]"
blue="\[\033[0;34m\]"
purple="\[\033[0;35m\]"
reset="\[\033[0m\]"

# Change command prompt
export GIT_PS1_SHOWDIRTYSTATE=1
# '\u' adds the name of the current user to the prompt
# '\$(__git_ps1)' adds git-related stuff
# '\W' adds the name of the current directory
export PS1="$purple\u$green\$(__git_ps1)$blue \W $ $reset"

# Color directory listings and things.
export CLICOLOR=1
```
Git prompt stuff for `.bash_profile` or `.bashrc`
